introText: You can use this test to assess your company's compliance with the obligations of a controller. After submitting your answers, you will receive a report with compiled feedback on your answers and recommended measures based on them.

questions.question: Does your company process personal data?

choices.selectedText: In practice, all companies process personal data to some extent. Activities such as the collection, storage, editing and erasure of personal data all constitute processing. Personal data includes all information that permits a person to be identified either directly or indirectly, such as their name, telephone number, email address or home address. The General Data Protection Regulation applies to personal data and imposes obligations on parties who process personal data. More information on the definition of personal data: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/what-is-personal-data More information on the definition of processing: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/processing-of-personal-data
choices.selectedActions: To be able to comply with personal data legislation, a company first has to understand what personal data it is processing and how. If you do not have a clear picture of the personal data you are processing, start by charting and identifying them. Review the personal data that your company is storing into various information systems. Do not forget to include data on paper.

questions.question: Has your company checked that it is only processing personal data that is necessary for the purposes of the processing?

choices.selectedText: You may not collect or process personal data more extensively than necessary for the purposes of processing. To assess the correct amount of personal data, you need to clearly identify the reason for which the personal data in question is necessary. The purpose of processing helps you define which personal data you need to process. The minimisation of personal data must be considered when collecting the data. If you use a form to collect data, you should remove fields that are not necessary for the purpose at hand. Neither should you store personal data just in case. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/minimisation-of-data
choices.selectedActions: Good. You should re-evaluate the necessity of personal data on a regular basis. Go through the data being collected by your company one more time and make sure that it is being collected for a specific purpose.

questions.question: Has your company specified storage times for personal data?

choices.selectedText: The controller must plan the storage time of personal data and be able to justify it. Personal data may only be stored for as long as necessary for the purpose of the processing. In other words, you must minimise the storage time. The GDPR does not specify precise storage times for personal data. The controller must evaluate the storage time and necessity of the personal data with regard to the purpose at hand. The personal data may also be subject to legislation, such as the Accounting Act, which requires or advises data to be stored for a certain time. The storage times of personal data must also be documented. It is important to clarify the start and end dates of data storage. You must also keep in mind that different storage times may apply to different types or groups of data. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/storage-limitation
choices.selectedActions: Great! Make sure that the storage times have been documented and the data subjects have been informed of them, for example in the privacy statement.

questions.question: Has your company specified how the erasure of personal data will be carried out in practice: when, how and by whom?

choices.selectedText: The controller is required to draw up instructions ensuring that the necessity of personal data is reviewed at regular intervals and unnecessary or obsolete personal data is erased or anonymised. In other words, the company should specify when personal data should be reviewed, by whom, and how unnecessary data should be erased. It would also be useful to consider whether your company could implement automatic data erasure at the end of the storage time. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/storage-limitation
choices.selectedActions: Great! You can also consider whether you could automate the erasure of personal data.

questions.question: If the data is anonymised instead of erased, has your company ensured that the identification of individuals from the data has been prevented irreversibly?

choices.selectedText: You should be aware of the difference between anonymisation and pseudonymisation. Pseudonymisation means processing personal data to make it impossible to connect the data to a specific individual without additional information. Individuals can still be picked out and identified by combining data from different data sets even if the data has been pseudonymised. Anonymisation means processing personal data so that individuals can no longer be identified from it. For example, the data can be aggregated to a general level or converted into statistics so that the data concerning individuals is rendered unrecognisable. Anonymisation must be irreversible for the data to be considered anonymous. More information on anonymisation: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/pseudonymised-and-anonymised-data
choices.selectedActions: Good. But read the guidelines for anonymisation. Finally, make sure that identification has been prevented irreversibly and so that the controller or a third party cannot render the data identifiable with data in their possession.

questions.question: Have you ensured that data subjects are sufficiently informed of the processing of their personal data?

choices.selectedText: The General Data Protection Regulation provides for the information you are required to give to data subjects. When informing the data subject, you are required to disclose information such as who the controller is, the purpose for which the data subject's personal data is necessary, for how long will the personal data be required, and the ways in which the data subject can exercise their personal data rights. Read more about what information you need to disclose to the data subject: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/informing-data-subjects-about-processing

questions.question: Has your company drawn up a written description of its processing of personal data (i.e. a record of processing activities)?

choices.selectedText: The record of processing activities is often confused with the privacy statement. The record of processing activities is an internal document intended to demonstrate the company's compliance with its data protection obligations (while the privacy statement is a document intended for data subjects). The record of processing activities contains information such as the purposes of processing and disclosures and storage times of data. In some cases, the General Data Protection Regulation requires a company to draw up a record of processing activities in accordance with the GDPR. Recording the processing of personal data is a useful way to maintain an overview of processing even when a written description is not required by the GDPR. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/record-of-processing-activities
choices.selectedActions: It is good that you have drawn up a record of processing activities. The document must also be updated on a regular basis.

You are free to use the following Excel template available on the website of the Office of the Data Protection Ombudsman: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/processor-s-record-of-processing-activities

questions.guideText: The record of processing activities is often confused with the privacy statement. The record of processing activities is an internal document intended to demonstrate the company's compliance with its data protection obligations (while the privacy statement is a document intended for data subjects). The record of processing activities contains information such as the purposes of processing and disclosures and storage times of data. In some cases, the General Data Protection Regulation requires a company to draw up a record of processing activities in accordance with the GDPR. Recording the processing of personal data is a useful way to maintain an overview of processing even when a written description is not required by the GDPR. More information: https://tietosuoja.fi/en/record-of-processing-activities
